titleStmt.title: William Morris to Thomas Pennant, 5 February 1760

div.p:
SupineThis word labels a diagram of a fish, showing it lying on its back.
ProneThis labels the same fish viewed lying on its belly. Note that in mentioning parts of the body in the text, William Morris refers to specific points in the diagram, with letter labels, given here as 'P', 'a', 'B'. See further below for Morris's own key to the diagrams.
Of this Size.The words refer to the diagram.

Taken in a Herring Net at
Holyhd. 7 December 1759. –
of a Dark yellowish Colour
with Brownish irregular Spots
interspersd with beautiful
streaks of light blue & yellow
the Body from the Anus to the
Tail all Transparent. the Vent2P
perfectly white thence downward
of a Dull white. the formost back fin
whose membrane was yellow, was most
beautifully streakd with light blue –
the Pupil of the Eye was perectly bxlack
& the Iris of a whitish Green with swelld
or vesicled lids. blowing in the foramens a
would Swell the Gills.B In the Ventricle
was found pieces of the Rays of Stella lacert;aThe 'Stella lacert' has not been identified. It seems unlikely that it is connected with the 'lacerta stellio', a lizard. See OED s.v. starry lizard.
It had a large milt or Oil Vessel of a yellow
white Colour. It had no Scales & was
Slippery. the fish when boild was firm
& hard and Delicious –––––
It was Exactly of this Size & Dimensions
x the Anus. t the Penis. none of the Fins prickly

The Length of this Fish was 19½ ft. is drawn by a Scale of 16 to an Inch (= 1 of the Cartilaginous kind
The Skin of a Sooty (Cloudy) Colur. extream rough against the Grain resembling in some things Dr. Grew's river whale in having small "Teeth
innumerable ^ standing like those in a Card. Gills descending almost from the Top of his Head meet under his throat."William Morris quotes from Nehemiah Grew, Musæum regalis societatis; or, A catalogue & description of the natural and artificial rarities belonging to the Royal Society and preserved at Gresham Colledge, p. 103. Grew's text refers to 'an innumerable company of prickly Teeth, standing like those in a Card wherewith Women Comb Wool'. Morris adds an icon for the teeth (given here as '^'). No Teeth
from x to x only a Socket like other whales, at x a Small vent hole wch. go downward to the roof the mouthQu Ears. The mouth by reason of the Gills
being so long wd. open to a Surprizing wideness so that a child of 5 or 6 year Old might sit therein. The Bach Fin pThe letter 'p' here refers to a label in the drawing of the fish. & part of the
Tail always appear above water when the Fish when the Fish Basking on the Surface which they do in great number on
a Sun Shiny day in Sum~er, are not Seen in winter. ––– One taken at Rhoscolyn in Sept. 1759. 27 foot long i.e. 27
yeelded 190 odd Gallons of Oil. The male have 2 Penis's and the Female 2 Apertures answerable thereto. –––
It hath but one Gut. no Ventricle distinguishable. The 2 Oil Vessels or Liver Surprizing large, no Blubber.

x And a hollow for them in the Body of the Fish. the Edges
of the Tail & Fins of that somewhat Jagg'd. The Two hind
Fins in that Opposite, The Fins nigh the Anus Small
x The Oil Vessel or liver very small.

[In Thomas Pennant's hand:] Does the vent Hole at x go thro' into
the mouth. [in William Morris's hand:] it goeth downward that way. –

Smith in His Nat Hist. of Cork calls this
"the Mola Sale. the Sun Fish but not the
Mola Salviani wch. Willoughby names the
Sun Fish" –For the quotation, see Charles Smith, The antient and present state of the county and city of Cork (Dublin, 1750), p. 299; and for the naming of the Mola Salviani as 'The Sun-fish', see Francis Willughby, De historia piscium libri quatuor (Oxford, 1686), p. 151. The Irish call it Herring Hog.For citations of the name 'herring-hog', described as a dialect word meaning 'the grampus', see OED s.v. herring.
Some, Bottle Noses –––––

It differs from the Shark in many respects the teeth
of the Shark are large & three pointed & in three rows
these here are not ¼ Inch long, round & bent. the Gills
of that reach not much above half way to the back
these almost quite up, that broad from the Small fins
to the Tail, this almost round, that wth. a Sharp Snout
this with a blunt round one. the Penis's much larger in that. x

I Blush to see your kind Lre lying before me unanswer'd owing to my not having time to Copy the New Fish, and now its done have Comitted a blunder by putting the Description on the Same paper which I beg ye will Excuse.For this material, see the enclosure to this letter.

In Answer to your Queries concerning the Large Fish, am to aquaint that they begin to Appear in the Irish Chanel betwixt this & Dublin in the Sum~er months, July & August June but dont come into the Bays till August & Continue till about the beginning or middle of November when they Disap~ear. their Size from 18 ft. to 28 or 30, The large ones produce 190 odd Gallons of oil the Small ones 60 or 80 galls. the Eye is Small in the Largest not much bigger than an Ox's but the Exact Size is exhibited in the Figure.Note that William Morris sent a drawing of a fish judged by Pennant to be a nondescript – quite possibly the same as the one enclosed with this letter of the same date to Pennant – with a letter of 5 February 1760 to his brother Lewis, asking for it to be returned as soon as possible, with its name on the back. See William Morris to Lewis Morris, 5 February 1760, in ML, II, p. 171. For other occasions on which Lewis sent responses to queries by William about fish, see [Dafydd Wyn Wiliam], 'Wiliam Morris at Thomas Pennant – Tri Llythyr: III', in Tlysau'r Hen Oesoedd, no. 20 ([October] 2006), 5 n. 2; Lewis Morris to William Morris, 18 September 1757, in ML, II, pp. 15–16; Lewis Morris to William Morris, 24 September 1757, in ibid., p. 21; and Lewis Morris to William Morris, 5 October 1757, in ibid., p. 24, where Lewis mentions that he has completed a drawing of a large fish and written a dissertation about it to be read before the Cymmrodorion Society. No food in the Stomach but a kind of thick Slimy matter. they dont seem to pursue The Herrings or any other Fish. The teeth are Set in an irreglular mañer and not in Rows. As to the FinA mark in the text here may have been intended to represent the fin under discussion. I am in doubt about it, whether it should not be underneath. Pray examine Willughby, if any other fish hath such on their Sides it must be right. Smith in his Nat. Histo. Waterford says that instead of Teeth itthis Fish is furnishd in the roof of the Mouth with horney bearded Laminæ, and seem in this respect to be somewhat of the Species which afford the Wholebone tho' unlike in other respects –William Morris quotes from Charles Smith, The antient and present state of the county and city of Waterford, p. 271, where two examples of 'Sun-fish' caught on the coast of Waterford in 1743 and 1744 are discussed: 'This fish instead of teeth is furnished in the roof of the mouth with several rows of horney bearded Laminæ, and seem in this respect to be somewhat of the species which affords the whalebone, though unlike it in other particulars.'
Vide Philo. Trans. No. 406 p. 243 for Jan. 40 where mention is made of one of these Fish being brot. into Plymo. June 29. 1734.–William Morris refers to 'A Paper concerning the Mola SALU. or Sun-fish, and a Glue made of it; communicated by the Rev. Mr. William Barlow to the President of the Royal Society', dated from 'Stoke-Dock near Plymouth, Devon, June 29. 1734', in Philosophical Transactions, vol. 41 (1739–1741), 343–5, see here.

I am proud to find that the other is like to turn out a Non descript. How could I know whether it was good without eating of it? –This comment is elucidated by William Morris's remarks to his brother Lewis regarding a fish which he and his daughter ate, to the great consternation of Pennant. See [Wiliam], 'Wiliam Morris at Thomas Pennant – Tri Llythyr: III', 5 n. 4; and William Morris to Lewis Morris, 17 March 1760, in ML, II, p. 184: 'Nid pysgodyn pigog gwenwynig oedd fy 'sgodyn i [Mine was not a stinging poisonous fish]; all his fins were soft and pliable. Oni ddarfu i fy merch a minnau ei fwyta fo, er bod y Bennant agos a dymunaw na busai asgwrn yn glynu yn fy ngwddwg am Esu Nondescript [Didn't my daughter and I eat it, although Pennant was almost wishing that a bone would stick in my throat for [?eating] a nondescript]'. I receivd the Two Books Safe and Sound & shall return them anon in the Same Condition with thanksThe borrowed books cannot be identified; but for a reference to Pennant's lending of books to William Morris, see 1405, n. 4. a Sight of Artedi will be Acceptable. am Sorry to find your Friend Linnæus is a Changeling. –William Morris, a keen botanist, may be referring to the increasing attention given by Linnaeus to the animal kingdom in the tenth edition of Systema Naturae (1758).

I am extream glad to hear that there is a Prospect of your having a Sucking Virtuoso,This refers to the firstborn of Thomas Pennant and his first wife, Elizabeth (née Falconer), who had already been born when William Morris wrote this letter. the Sight would be extreamly agreeable to your humble Servt. but I must not flatter my self with so great a happiness.William Morris's wife Jane (née Hughes) had died during 1750 and he remained single after that, although father to two children from his marriage to her. See Dafydd Wyn Wiliam, Cofiant William Morris (1705–63) (Llangefni: Yr Awdur, 1995), pp. 96, 100–101, 102. May you & your Lovely Spouse be blessd with it, is the hearty wish of Good Sir

closer.salute:
Your most obliged & most Obedient
humble Servt. & Pupil

postscript.p:
PS. I am at a loss for a Frank Have none of yours, I returnd one in Lieu of it. – Yonder is Ellis the Coralinist gone to rack & ruin I thot. Virtuosii were made of tougher matter, than it seems some of them are.John Ellis was bankrupted during 1759. ODNB.
I must Hazzard this Pacqt. wth. a Guide for want of a Frank.–
